Norns live in Asgård, at the foot of the world tree Yggdrasil and by the well of Urd, where they spin the thread of destiny for each person born. According to one legend, Urd spins the threads, Verdandi twists them together, and Skuld cuts the thread. However, nothing lasts forever, and even Yggdrasil is bound to wither. The Norns try to prevent this, or at least slow down the process, by pouring mud and water from the well of fate on the roots of the world tree. The magical liquid stops the rotting for the time being. Norn myths

Eduskunta (i.e. Parliament) is the Finnish parliament, i.e. the body exercising the state's legislative and budgetary powers. In addition, the parliament supervises the government's activities and participates in the European Union's decision-making. In the past, the parliaments of other countries were also called eduskunn in the Finnish language, for example in the "Big Encyclopedia" published between 1931–1958, but nowadays the word is used only for the Finnish parliament. According to the Constitution of Finland, state power in Finland belongs to the people, "represented by the parliament assembled for the Diet" (PL § 2). The Parliament consists of 200 MPs, who are elected every four years in parliamentary elections (PL § 24–25). In accordance with parliamentary principles, the State Council exercising governmental power must "enjoy the confidence of the parliament" (PL § 3). The counted tickets and minutes are delivered to the central election board of the municipality in municipal elections and to the electoral district board in other elections. Before the elections, Statistics Finland publishes statistics on the backgrounds of the candidates and after the elections an analysis of the results. The members of the Finnish parliament are elected by direct, proportional and secret elections. Elections are conducted by electoral district, which currently has 13. The biggest sacrificial feasts in the Viking Age were perhaps held in Uppsala, Sweden, and Lejre, Denmark. Only descriptions of both have been preserved by Christian authors, so the information may be distorted. Both festivals were held every ninth year and people as well as animals were sacrificed. The number nine had some kind of magical meaning. It was said that 99 people, a horse, a dog and a rooster were sacrificed in Lejre. The island, which belongs to the province of Saaremaa, has less than 200 mainly Estonian inhabitants, and its area is 11.9 square kilometers. The nearest populated area on the mainland is Kolka in the Curonian Spit of Latvia, which is 37 kilometers from Ruhnu. Before 1944, the island was inhabited for hundreds of years by Estonian-Swedes, whose livelihood had been farming, fishing and seal hunting. During World War II, the Estonian-Swedish population was evacuated to Sweden. The settlement after that dates back to the Soviet era. Today, Ruhnu municipality has only one village, Ruhnu village, which is located in the central part of the island. Ruhnu is 5.5 kilometers long and 3.5 kilometers wide. It has formed on the ridge of the seabed in the southeast-northwest direction of the Gulf of Riga. From the seabed

split_passages_en: Horatio Walpole, 4th Earl of Orford, better known as Horace Walpole (24 September 1717 London, United Kingdom – 2 March 1797) was an English art historian, writer and politician. He is remembered today for the villa he built on London's Strawberry Hill and his Gothic novel The Castle of Otranto (1764). Horatio Walpole was born to Robert and Catherine Walpole. His father, Robert Walpole, was a famous Whig politician who also became the Prime Minister of Great Britain. Horatio was educated at home until he entered Eton College in 1727. He entered King's College, Cambridge, in March 1735. However, he left school before graduating in 1738. After college, Horace Walpole went on a European tour with his friend, the poet Thomas Gray. Walpole returned to London in 1741, and he

was elected to the British Parliament in the same year. He sat in Parliament until 1768, but he still did not have a significant career as a politician. In 1749, Walpole acquired a small villa in Twickenham, London. He expanded the building and its courtyard with two of his friends according to the principles of Georgian architecture. They added breastworks and turrets to the villa. They also expanded the garden and did some landscaping. The building was giving impetus to the popularity of neo-Gothic in English architecture. Inspired by his new Gothic building, Walpole wrote the novel The Castle of Otranto, often considered the first Gothic novel. It was published in 1764. split_passages_en: Thrasyllus of Mendes, full name Tiberius Claudius Thrasyllus (d. 36 CE) was an Egyptian astrologer, astronomer and mathematician who lived during the reign of Emperor Tiberius and served under him. He was known for the accuracy of his astronomical calculations. Today, Thrasyllus is best known for publishing one of the earliest complete editions of Plato's works and arranging Plato's works into tetralogies, or groups of four works. According to Diogenes Laertius, Thrasyllus had claimed that Plato himself organized the dialogues into tetralogies in the same way that Greek plays were organized into groups of four acts, each containing three tragedies and one satyr play. Apparently, Polycrates was popular with the people, and his opponents, mainly representatives of the old aristocracy, were driven into exile. Possibly Pythagoras was one of those who went into exile. Polykrates improved the defense of the city of Samos by building walls around the city. At the same time, he built a rocky pier in its harbor to protect it from invaders. passage_in_language: <0> Tuomas Akvinolainen (; 1225 Roccasecca – 7. maaliskuuta 1274 Fossanova) oli italialainen katolinen filosofi, teologi ja pappi, joka edusti skolastista koulukuntaa. Katolinen kirkko itse pitää aristoteelista perinnettä ja kristinuskoa yhdistänyttä ajattelijaa suurimpana teologinaan, ja hän onkin yksi kirkonopettajista latinankielisillä kutsumanimillä "Doctor angelicus" eli "enkelimäinen tohtori" ja "Doctor communis" eli "yleinen tohtori". Hänen ajattelunsa on tomismin nimellä edelleen katolisen kirkon teologian ja etiikan perustana. Miestä kunnioitetaan katolisuudessa, anglikaanisuudessa ja luterilaisuudessa. Paavi Johannes XXII kanonisoi Tuomaan 18. heinäkuuta 1323 ja häntä pidetään esimerkiksi koulujen, yliopistojen, teologien, kirjojen myyjien, Italian ja siveyden suojeluspyhimyksenä. Pyhimyksen juhlaa vietetään 28. tammikuuta. Landulfin veli Sinibald toimi apottina ensimmäisessä benediktiiniluostarissa Monte Cassinossa. Tämä oli luonnollinen urapolku myös Tuomaan kaltaiselle nuoremmalle aatelispojalle. Tuomas aloitti varhaiset opintonsa luostarissa viiden vuoden ikäisenä. Vuonna 1236 hän siirtyi Napolin yliopistoon, jossa hän päätyi dominikaanisääntökunnan vaikutuksen alle. Tuomaan ajattelu on vaikuttanut suuresti kristilliseen teologiaan, erityisesti katoliseen teologiaan, ja koko eurooppalaiseen filosofiaan yleensä. 1800-luvulla hänen mukaansa nimetty tomismi saavutti virallisen aseman katolisessa kirkossa. Hänen hyve-etiikkansa on vieläkin katolisen kirkon viralliseksi kanonisoituneen kannan lähellä. Filosofiassa hän on ollut merkittävä aristotelismin uudistaja. split_passages_en: Thomas Aquinas (; 1225 Roccasecca – 7 March 1274 Fossanova) was an Italian Catholic philosopher, theologian and priest who represented the scholastic school. The Catholic Church itself considers the thinker who combined the Aristotelian tradition and Christianity as its greatest theologian, and he is indeed one of the church teachers with the Latin nicknames "Doctor angelicus" or "angelic doctor" and "Doctor communis" or "common doctor". His thinking, under the name of Thomism, is still the basis of the theology and ethics of the Catholic Church. The man is respected in Catholicism, Anglicanism and Lutheranism. Pope John XXII canonized Thomas on July 18, 1323, and he is considered the patron saint of schools, universities, theologians, booksellers, Italy, and chastity. When word of Philip's defeat reached Rome, Philip's son, Philip the Younger, was murdered by the Praetorian Guard. Decius marched to Rome and received Senate confirmation of his emperorship, probably in the fall of 249. A papyrus document found in Egypt states that Decius' reign began on November 28, but October 16 is also a possible date. Immediately after becoming emperor, Decius decided to add the name Traianus to his names to refer to the conquering emperor Trajanus, who ruled about 150 years earlier and was considered one of the greatest emperors after Augustus. An altar was later erected at the site of the battle, which was still famous in the fourth century. Although Christian historians of antiquity treated Decius with hostility, non-Christian historians always spoke of Decius in a positive tone. After the disaster at Abrittus, Decius and Herennius were probably deified, perhaps in the latter half of June 251. However, there is evidence that, possibly to protect his own reputation, Gallus ordered the memories of Decius and Herennius damned ("damnatio memoriae") in July 251. Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus Decius (c. 190–200 – June 251) was Roman emperor from 249–251. He was the first emperor to come from the provinces bordering the Danube. Decius was appointed commander of Moesia and Pannonia by the emperor Philippus Arabs in 249. However, Decius rebelled against Philippus and defeated his forces in battle. Philippus was killed and Decius became emperor. He appointed his sons Herennius Etruscus and Hostilianus as his heirs and later elevated Herennius to co-ruler. During the short reign of Decius, he had to fight against the Carps and Goths who invaded Dacia and Moesia. He also built a bath in Rome on the Aventinus and carried out a systematic persecution of Christians. Decius managed only two

Gaius Aurelius Valerius Diocletianus (c. 230 – 3 December 313) was Roman Emperor from 20 November 284 – 1 May 305. He was born in Illyria as the son of a freed slave named Diocles (). As emperor, Diocletian stabilized the conditions of Rome and during his reign the unstable crisis of the 200s was brought to an end. Among other things, Diocletian reformed taxation and tried to stop the depreciation of money. He reformed the army, and the security of the country increased so that the Roman Empire was not threatened by barbarian invasions or internal rebellions. Diocletian renewed the supreme power of Rome by establishing the tetrarchy, where four emperors divided the empire among themselves. The country was divided into western and eastern parts, each ruled by a senior emperor who used the name "Augustus". Diocletian chose as his co-ruler

split_passages_en: A television receiver, abbreviated as television or TV, is a device used to receive television broadcasts. The television receiver can also be used as a monitor and speakers for a computer, DVD player or game console. In 1926, Scotsman John Logie Baird (1888–1946) developed the first device that could display an electrical signal as an image. The device was electromechanical, using Nibkow's plate, and its number of lines was only 30 at first. Nibkow had time to see a demonstration of Baird's "Televisor" system in Berlin in 1928. In the United States, Nibkow's method was used by Charles Francis Jenkins (1867–1934), whose own device was completed after Baird. Jenkins started television broadcasting in 1928, when the transmitting and receiving equipment was based on electromechanical technology. The sound was sent separately using radio technology and synchronized in the receiver. The image quality was so bad that the technique

most mechanical scan systems, in both the transmitter and receiver. Constantin Perskyi had coined the word "television" in a paper read to the International Electricity Congress at the International World Fair in Paris on August 24, 1900. Perskyi's paper reviewed the existing electromechanical technologies, mentioning the work of Nipkow and others. However, it was not until 1907 that developments in amplification tube technology, by Lee de Forest and Arthur Korn among others, made the design practical. By the 1920s when amplification made television practical, Scottish inventor John Logie Baird employed the Nipkow disk in his prototype video systems. On March

tube" (cathode ray tube or "CRT") in the receiver. Moving images were not possible because, in the scanner, "the sensitivity was not enough and the selenium cell was very laggy". By the 1920s, when amplification made television practical, Scottish inventor John Logie Baird employed the Nipkow disk in his prototype video systems. He created his prototype in a little village called Santa Cruz on the island of Trinidad where he was recovering from an illness. He had also started work on the first color television. On March 25, 1925, Baird gave the first public demonstration of televised silhouette images in

1927 Russian inventor Léon Theremin While living in the United States developed image interlacing. Interlacing reduces image flicker. All-electric television was developed by Philo Farnsworth (1906–1971), Vladimir Zworykin (1888–1982) in the United States, and Kálmán Tihanyi (1897–1947) in Hungary. A device using Farnsworth's "image disector" was introduced in 1927–1929. Zworykin worked at Westinghouse developing the "iconoscope". Zworykin's device was the first to be patented in 1925, but it could only display a still image. Farnsworth and RCA, which acquired Zworyk's patent, got into a patent dispute. Electronic television worked for the first time in 1926, when Zworyk and Farnsworth's patents were combined with Tihany's camera tube. Tihanyi had developed his camera tube for his radioscope in 1926. The first public television broadcasts started in black and white in Germany in 1934. The technology had already been tried since 1929

Lukkoleuka on epäinhimillisten kaltainen olento, jonka todellisesta muodosta ei olla aivan varmoja. Uskotaan hänen olleen joskus inhimillinen olento, kuten suurin osa muistakin epäinhimillisistä. Myöhemmin hän kuitenkin mutatoitui terrigeenisumun vuoksi koiramaiseksi olennoksi. Väitteen todenperäisyys on kuitenkin kiistanalainen. Saattaa myös olla mahdollista, että Lukkoleuka on vain epäinhimillisten epätavanomainen koira.
split_passages_en: Lilo Pelekai is a fictional character in Disney's Lilo & Stitch movies and television series. She is a lively Hawaiian girl without parents, but still belongs to a special family. Lilo's original voice actress is Daveigh Chase, in Finland she is Annituuli Kasurinen and Ada Forsberg. Lilo and her older sister Nani's parents died in a car accident, so nowadays they have to live alone. Nani is Lilo's official guardian, but the balance between work and everyday life doesn't quite work out, so social worker Cobra Bubbles threatens to take Lilo away if things don't start going well. Lilo is quite lonely. His only friend besides Nani is Molla, a rag doll he made himself. The other girls, Mertle, Yuki, Elena and Teresa,

Lalli Leonard Leipäjuusto () is a fictional main antagonist in the Prätkähiiret series. The character created by Rick Ungari made his first appearance in 1993 in the episode "Hanata auki!" of the animated series "Prätkähiiret". Plutolainen Leipäjuusto is the full name of Lalli Leonardo Lactose Leipäjuusto. He got his name from the Limburger cheese (in English) and from the cheese of the same name in Finnish. He uses a mask to infiltrate the countrymen. Bread cheese is a scheming, ambitious, two-faced and egotistical opponent. He was given the task of collecting natural resources from Earth for the Plutonians to Pluto, but it is not easy because the Prätkä mice are always blocking his intentions. Leipäjuusto's assistant is Professor Nuikki, who also asked for help from other opponents whom Leipäjuusto wanted for certain tasks. His other sidekick is Fatskin, who is truly a hopeless case. Bread cheese

Lepinkäinen is a supervillain appearing in comics from the Marvel publishing house. Lepinkäinen's first appearance was in the first issue of "Rampaging Hulk" magazine (January 1977). The character was created by Doug Moench and Walt Simonson. Lepinkäinen has great physical strength, which allows him to lift an estimated thousand kilos. Lepinkäinen's reflexes, suppleness, endurance and ability to tolerate injuries have also been enhanced to their limits. Lepinkäinen can fly with the help of surgically implanted anti-gravity units (located in Lepinkäinen's spine). The unit is activated by nerve impulses. With the device, Lepinkäinen can fly up to 128 km/h. He is also able to carry about 200 kg of cargo (including himself) while flying. Among Lepinkäinen's other devices, let's mention his suit, which is made of a durable steel alloy. The metal of the suit can withstand even small-caliber bullets

Lukkoleuka (also known as Pihtileuka in Finland) is a superhero created by the Marvel publishing house, a pet of the Inhuman royal family. Lockjaw first appeared in "Fantastic Four" issue #45 (December 1965). The character was created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby. Because of the deformity, Lockjaw resembles a huge bulldog and has enormous physical strength. In addition, he is able to teleport with his friends almost anywhere. A lockjaw is an inhuman-like creature whose true form is uncertain. It is believed that he was once a human being, like most of the other inhumans. However, he later mutated into a dog-like creature due to the terrigen fog. However, the veracity of the claim is debatable. It may also be possible that Lockjaw is just an unusual dog of the Inhumans.

Christopher Reeve esitti Teräsmiestä vuoden 1978 elokuvassa "Teräsmies", joka sai suitsutusta kriitikoilta ja josta tuli Warner Brosin tuon aikakauden elokuvista menestyksekkäin. Vuonna 2006 ilmestyi "Superman Returns" -elokuva, joka oli jatko-osa vanhoille Christopher Reeve -elokuville. split_passages_en: Criminology is a multidisciplinary discipline that can be considered part of criminal law or alternatively part of legal sociology. It is mainly an empirical science that studies crime as a social phenomenon. Research targets include the amount, quality, development and causes of crime. Decision-making regarding crime and its prevention can also be read as part of criminal law, although other social sciences also play a significant role in it. The goal of crime prevention is to prevent or reduce crime and increase safety through these means. Here we can emphasize situational prevention or social prevention of crime, which means preventing the commission of crimes on a personal level or preventing them from continuing to commit them. You can also focus, for example, on designing the built environment in such a way that it produces as much as possible

Criminology studies crime as a social phenomenon mainly using empirical methods. The research object can be the amount, structure, development, factors affecting crime and its causes. Criminology is multidisciplinary and it can be placed as its own discipline in the context of legal sociology or criminal law. It also has connections with economics, social policy and statistics. The positivist criminology of the beginning of the 20th century saw crime as mostly tied to individual characteristics. This trend was represented by Cesare Lombroso and Hans Eysenck, among others. Since the causes of crime were seen at the individual level, solutions were also sought at the individual level. Lombroso emphasized the biological and genetic characteristics of the criminal, and later criminologists have been critical of his research methods. Positivist criminology also took the definition of the concept of crime for granted, and focused on studying crime and crime statistics

Criminology is a discipline whose research object is crimes, criminality, punishments and related social phenomena. Criminal sciences is a general concept used especially in the Nordic countries, which is part of public law. Criminal sciences include the following areas:

The legal order formed by legal norms is studied by jurisprudence. The legality basis of criminal law prohibits condemning anyone for an act that was not specifically ordered to be punished at the time of its commission. The science that studies crime is called criminology. The Finnish legal system, like almost all Western legal systems, is usually divided into private law and public law. The former concerns the mutual relations between individuals and legal entities, and the latter concerns their relations with public entities, such as municipalities and the state. Many private legal acts are discretionary, i.e. dispositive, which means that the parties involved can agree on matters with each other, contrary to what is stipulated in the law. In this case, the law will only apply, unless otherwise agreed. Instead, public law and some private law regulations are "mandatory" i.e. indispositive and cannot be negotiated

The Aegean Sea or "Aegean Sea" (, ) is an island part of the Mediterranean Sea located between the Balkan Peninsula and Asia Minor. It is connected to the Black Sea via the Dardanelles, the Sea of ​​Marmara and the Bosphorus. The Aegean islands belong to Greece, with a few exceptions. The sea is Greece's most significant sea area, along with the Ionian Sea. In antiquity, there were several explanations for the name Aegean. It was said to have been named after the city of Aigai, known as a cult place for Poseidon, Aigea, queen of the Amazons, or Aigeus, father of Theseus, who drowned himself in the sea thinking his son was dead. The etymology of the name can also be based on the word "aiges" (αἶγες, 'waves'), in which case it could mean "Wavy sea". The area of ​​the Aegean Sea is approximately 215,000 square kilometers. split_passages_en: Emily Jane Brontë (30 July 1818 – 19 December 1848) was an English novelist and poet. She was one of the so-called Brontë literary sisters. Her sisters were Charlotte and Anne Brontë. Brontë's first novel was "The Humming Ridge", published in 1847. Matematiikka ei tutki ympäröivää, fysikaalista todellisuutta, vaan käsitteellisiä riippuvuussuhteita. Tämän takia sitä ei yleensä lueta luonnontieteisiin, vaikka matematiikan ja matemaattisten menetelmien soveltaminen on tärkeä osa luonnontieteitä ja monet matematiikan tutkimusongelmat ovat peräisin luonnontieteistä, erityisesti fysiikasta. Esimerkiksi Isaac Newtonin <2> filosofia on osittain päällekkäistä metafysiikan kanssa sikäli, että jotkut siihen kuuluvat näkemykset ovat realistisia matemaattisten olioiden suhteen, ja katsovat näiden olioiden olevan olemassa joko transsendentaalisesti, fysikaalisesti tai mentaalisesti. Platonisen realismin mukaan matemaattiset oliot ovat olemassa transsendentaalisessa ei-fysikaalisten olioiden todellisuudessa. Matemaattisen empirismin mukaan matemaattiset oliot ovat tavallisia fysikaalisia olioita. Tämä tarkoittaa, että esimerkiksi kolmiot ovat olemassa fysikaalisesti. Intuitionismin mukaan kaikki matemaattiset totuudet ovat kokemuksellisia ja matematiikka on ihmisten suorittamaa konstruktiivista mentaalista toimintaa. Muut matematiikanfilosofiset näkökannat, kuten formalismi ja fiktionalismi, eivät myönnä matemaattisten olioiden olemassaoloa ja ovat näin antirealistisia. Länsimaisen matematiikan filosofian juuret ovat Platonissa, joka tutki matemaattisten olioiden ontologista asemaa, ja
split_passages_en: Philosophy of mathematics is a branch of philosophy that studies the philosophical foundations, assumptions and consequences of mathematics. Themes of the philosophy of mathematics include: The terms "philosophy of mathematics" and "mathematical philosophy" can be seen either as the same or separate. The latter can be understood in three ways. First, it can be understood as an effort to define some philosophical subject area, such as aesthetics, ethics, logic, metaphysics or theology in a more precise and strictly defined form. This was typical of scholastic philosophers and the systems of Gottfried Leibniz and Baruch Spinoza. Secondly, it can be understood as the working philosophy of a mathematician or a community of mathematicians. Third, it can be seen as referring to the mathematical philosophy approach applied by Bertrand Russell in his "Introduction to Mathematical Philosophy" ("Introduction to Mathematical Philosophy"). Mathematics

Mathematics is a formal or conceptual science based on deductive reasoning. In mathematics, numbers, quantities, structures, changes and spaces are studied, among other things. According to mathematical formalism, mathematics is the study of axiomatically defined abstract structures by means of symbolic logic and a mathematical notation system. Mathematics is used as a "language" for expressing physical and conceptual relationships, whose grammar and terminology are extremely precisely defined. This makes it possible to express things unambiguously, assuming that the logical structures remain unchanged. Mathematics does not study the surrounding, physical reality, but conceptual dependencies. Because of this, it is not usually counted among the natural sciences, even though the application of mathematics and mathematical methods is an important part of the natural sciences and many research problems in mathematics originate from the natural sciences, especially physics. For example, Isaac Newton

philosophy partially overlaps with metaphysics in that some of its views are realist about mathematical entities, and consider these entities to exist either transcendentally, physically, or mentally. According to Platonic realism, mathematical entities exist in the transcendental reality of non-physical entities. According to mathematical empiricism, mathematical objects are ordinary physical objects. This means that, for example, triangles exist physically. According to intuitionism, all mathematical truths are experiential and mathematics is a constructive mental activity performed by humans. Other mathematical philosophical viewpoints, such as formalism and fictionalism, do not admit the existence of mathematical objects and are thus anti-realistic. Western philosophy of mathematics has its roots in Plato, who studied the ontological status of mathematical entities, and

Five of the twelve most important crops in the world today are cereals: wheat, corn, rice, barley and sorghum. These five types of cereals produce more than half of the nutritional energy used by mankind. Cereals can be divided into two groups according to their main use. Some of the grains are used directly for human consumption, mainly as bread grain, while some are used mainly for feeding animals, i.e. as fodder grain. Bread grains include wheat and rye, while corn, barley and oats are used more as feed grains. The food crisis that has shaken the world since 2008 has been caused

Orujo (galegos ourujo) is a spirit traditionally made in the northwestern parts of Spain. It is made by distilling using the waste from wine production. The home of Orujo is generally considered to be the province of Galicia, but it is also known in the autonomous regions of Asturias, Castile and León, and Cantabria. Depending on the language and context, the names oruxo, aguardiente, augardente and aguardiente de orujo may also be used for orujo. Galicians have been making orujo since the 17th century. Nowadays, more than 20 producers make orujo, which are allowed to use the official designation "La Denominación Específica Orujo de Galicia". Although the Galician orujo is probably the most famous, the drink is also made elsewhere. One of the most traditional production places is Liébana in the province of Cantabria, whose monasteries have been making orujo since the Middle Ages. Orujo's main raw material

is a symbiotic nitrogen fixation typical of pea plants. When soybeans are crushed, 78 percent of soybean meal precursor soybean pulp, 18 percent raw soybean oil and 3 percent soybean fiber are produced. Soy meal made from soybeans can be used not only as animal feed but also as ground meat. Crude soybean oil is further refined into soybean oil and lecithin, which is a common emulsifier in, for example, chocolate, ready-made sauces, margarines and salted snacks. Other products made from soy include soy milk, soy sauce and tofu. Soy can also be used as biofuel. Soybean cultivation has been tried in Finland. In 2017, the cultivated area was 2.5 hectares. In warm regions in Sweden, it would be possible to increase the soybean cultivation area to 8000–9000 hectares, but the availability and price of imported fodder have not led to this. The Chinese called soybeans the golden pearl because of their nutritional value.

split_passages_en: Nagaland is a state in the northeastern part of India. Its area is 16,579 km². In 2011, its population is 1,978,502. Most of the inhabitants are Christians. The capital of Nagaland is Kohima. The official language of Nagaland is English. Most of the state is mountainous, criss-crossed by rivers. It has a monsoon climate with a dry season and a rainy season. Annual rainfall varies between 1,800 and 2,500 millimeters. Administratively, Nagaland is divided into 11 districts. Nagaland's neighboring states are Manipur to the south, Assam to the west and north, and Arunachal Pradesh to the northeast. To the east, Nagaland's border neighbor is the state of Myanmar.

coastal plains. In the interior, especially in the southeastern part of the country, the terrain is highlands covered by savannah. The highest point of the upland area rises 300 meters above sea level. The climate of Guinea-Bissau is tropical. The air is warm and humid all year round; the annual average temperature is about 27 degrees Celsius. The rainy season, tinged by inconsistent hailstorms and controlled by the monsoon, typically lasts from June to October, and the dry season from November to May. Harmattan winds sometimes blow from the Sahara during the dry season. The Bissago Islands in the Atlantic off the African continent also belong to Guinea-Bissau. At the same time, the Bijagós Islands form a biosphere reserve listed by UNESCO. In the southern parts of the region is Orango National Park (Parque Nacional de Orango), the largest of the country's national parks. The main rivers are Cacheu, Mansoa, Geba and Corubal. The Geba, Cacheu and Corubal rivers form an important hinterland

Bandiagara–Hombor highland () is a natural area in the central part of Mali. It mainly belongs to the Mopti region, extending to Timbuktu in the northeast and Ségou in the south. In the middle of the highlands are the 450-800 meter high Dogon Plateau and the Gandamia and Hombo mountains. To the south is the Bobo plateau and to the north is the Dyoundé-Erensis region. The Dogon, or Bandiagara, plateau borders on the 300–600 meter high, 200 km long Bandiagara rock slope, with the Gondo-Séno plateau on the east side. In the west, the highlands descend gently into the floodplain of the Niger inland delta. The Gandami mountains near Douentza rise to a height of 500-600 meters. The highest place in Mali is Homborivuori, 1155 meters high, rising above the Gourma plateau. Ylänkö is located in the catchment area of ​​the Niger tributary Yamé. As a result of increased drought, it now belongs almost entirely to the Sahel zone.

The golden langur ("Trachypithecus geei") is an orange-tailed monkey found only in a small area in the foothills of the Himalayas, most notably in the Manas National Park in Assam, India. Its residential area has decreased by more than 30% in the last 10 years. It is one of the most endangered monkey species in Asia. Goldfish are herbivores that eat succulent leaves, fruits and seeds. They live in herds of 2-12 individuals in forests and are most active in the mornings and evenings.

Montgomery syntyi Lontoossa 1887. Ylennys luutnantiksi seurasi vuonna 1910. Ensimmäinen maailmansota alkoi elokuussa 1914, jolloin hän siirtyi rykmenttinsä mukana Ranskaan, jossa osallistui Monsin vetäytymistaisteluihin. Hän haavoittui vaikeasti Ypresissä 13. lokakuuta 1914 osallistuessaan hyökkäykseen saksalaisten hallussaan pitämään Méterenin kylään, jossa Montgomery sai tarkka-ampujan luodin oikean keuhkonsa läpi <1> komentajaksi evakuoinnin aikana ja hän oli yksi yli 330 000 brittiläisestä ja ranskalaisesta sotilaasta, jotka evakuoitiin onnistuneesti Dunkerquesta operaation päättymiseen 4. kesäkuuta mennessä. split_passages_en: Bernard Law Montgomery (Montgomery, 1st Viscount Alamein, "Monty") (17 November 1887 London – 24 March 1976 Alton, Hampshire) was a British field marshal best known for taking part in major battles of the Second World War on the Allied side. Montgomery was born in London in 1887. After studying at St. Paul's School and the Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst, he joined the 1st Battalion of the Royal Warwickshire Regiment as a second lieutenant in 1908, initially serving in India. A promotion to lieutenant followed in 1910. The First World War began in August 1914, when he moved with his regiment to France, where he participated in the withdrawal battles of Mons. He was severely wounded at Ypres on 13 October 1914, taking part in an attack on the German-held village of Méteren, where Montgomery received a sniper's bullet through his right lung

Shortly after returning to Britain, he was promoted to lieutenant general and, after various posts in the home islands, was appointed commander of the 8th Army in North Africa in August 1942 after the original appointee, William Gott, had been killed when his plane was shot down en route to Cairo. Montgomery's actions in assuming command of the Eighth Army deeply angered Auchinleck and his outgoing staff. Montgomery announced that he had taken command of the Eighth Army on August 12, 1942, against the instructions he had received when he had been sent to familiarize himself with the army. to his old regiment and in 1947 he became the regiment's honorary colonel. In 1937, he became the commander of the 9th brigade and in the same year his wife died of illness. The following year he was promoted to major general and given command of the 8th Division in Palestine. The United Kingdom declared war on Nazi Germany on 3 September 1939, two days after Germany had invaded Poland. At the time, Montgomery had just taken command of the 3rd Division and was sent with his division to Belgium as part of the British Expeditionary Force (BEF). The Germans invaded the Netherlands on 8 May 1940 and the BEF was eventually forced to withdraw to the area around Dunkirk, with the BEF and French forces evacuating to Great Britain in Operation Dynamo from 26 May. Montgomery was assigned to II Army Corps

for Operation Torch, the invasion of French North Africa. DDR2 SDRAM (for the acronym in English Double Data Rate type two Synchronous Dynamic Random-Access Memory) is a type of RAM, from the SDRAM family used since the early 1970s. DDR2 modules work with 4 bits per cycle, that is, 2 out and 2 back in the same cycle, substantially improving the potential bandwidth under the same frequency of a traditional DDR SDRAM (if a real 200 MHz DDR delivered a nominal 400 MHz, the DDR2 for those same real 200 MHz delivers 800 MHz nominal). The wagon became familiar to Western military intelligence at the November 1967 Red Square parade. The wagon represented a completely new way of thinking in mechanized warfare, even causing panic among the defense forces of Western countries. The improved version of the vehicle, the BMP-2, became public only in September 1982, although it had already been the basic equipment of the Red Army for several years. What distinguishes the BMP from previous armored personnel carriers is that it was the first fully armored tracked personnel carrier armed with a carriage cannon. This feature made the wagon the first true infantry fighting vehicle. split_passages_en: New Technology File System (abbreviation NTFS) is a file system designed by Microsoft, which was released in 1993, along with Windows NT 3.1. NTFS evolved from the HPFS file system that was designed as part of the OS/2 project shared by IBM and Microsoft and based on the principles of the Files-11 file management system, which was designed for DEC's PDP-11 computers and was also used by the VMS operating system of VAX computers. NTFS was designed to replace the FAT file system and introduced many improvements to it. NTFS includes a variety of improvements over FAT, such as - support for extremely large files (up to 2 bytes), an access control list (which allows users to set access rights at the level of individual files), journaling, compression

Windows NT is an operating system family developed by Microsoft. The abbreviation NT stands for "New Technology". Unlike Microsoft's DOS-based Windows operating systems intended for consumer use, NT had proper memory protection for demanding multitasking applications, which made it significantly more reliable. Windows NT was a high-level programming language-based, processor-independent, multi-processor-supporting, multi-user operating system comparable in features to Unix. NT was also the first 32-bit Windows, when Windows systems made for consumer use at the time were 16/32-bit hybrids. Microsoft started the development of NT in November 1989. At that time, Microsoft was a subcontractor of IBM in the development of the OS/2 operating system. Microsoft had supplied IBM with the graphical user interfaces for the first two versions of the OS/2 operating system. As a result of the success of Windows 3.0, Microsoft withdrew from the OS/2 collaboration, and published with IBM

WinFS ("Windows Future Storage") was a SQL-based relational database engine for the NTFS file system developed for Microsoft's Windows operating system. WinFS is not a file system and does not replace FAT or NTFS file systems, but its purpose was to add a built-in SQL database engine to the NTFS file system. It was supposed to work like Spotlight from Apple's OS X. It prepares a database of the contents of the computer's hard drive and uses it to facilitate the organization and editing of data. WinFS is based on the OFS file system developed by Microsoft in 1990, which was mainly intended as a replacement for NTFS in the Windows NT operating system. HPFS was OS/2 Warp4 technology and Microsoft wanted to create a file system that would correct its shortcomings. Melvin Robert "Bom" Laird (September 1, 1922 in Omaha, Nebraska – November 16, 2016 in Florida) was an American politician of the Republican Party. He served as his country's defense minister during the Vietnam War in 1969–1973. What he initially proposed was the concept of "Vietnamization", which means the effort to gradually replace US forces with South Vietnam's own forces. As a result, the United States began to withdraw from the region in 1973. Laird graduated from Carleton College in Minnesota in 1942 and served in the United States Navy until April 1946. Laird's father, Melvin Sr. was a Wisconsin state senator, and he himself entered the Wisconsin Senate at the age of 23. He sat in the United States House of Representatives from Wisconsin's 7th congressional district from 1953 to 1969.

passage_in_language: <0> Oppivelvollisuuslaki oli Suomen oppivelvollisuutta koskeva laki, joka vahvistettiin 15. huhtikuuta vuonna 1921. Suomeen laki oppivelvollisuudesta tuli eurooppalaisessa lainsäätämisympäristössä varsin myöhään, ja vain Belgiassa saatiin asiaa käsittelevä laki vielä Suomenkin jälkeen. Suomessa ei oppivelvollisuuslaki, toisin kuin melkein kaikissa muissa länsimaissa, aseta koulupakkoa, vaan säätää opittavaksi määrätyt muulla lainsäädännöillä ja asetuksilla määriteltävät asiat. Nykyään Suomessa perusopetuksesta ja oppivelvollisuudesta säädetään perusopetuslaissa. Suomen teollinen nousu 1860-luvulta lähtien vaikutti suuresti myös maan sivistyksellisiin pyrkimyksiin ja kansan elinolosuhteisiin. Näin tulivat voimaan kieliasetukset, maakaupan vapauttaminen, kansakoulu sekä tietenkin maapäivien (valtiopäivien) säännöllinen toiminta. Uutta suomalaisessa yhteiskunnassa oli liikkuvuus, sillä palkollissäännöt olivat poistuneet ja ihmiset saivat vapaasti muuttaa niin <1> Oppivelvollisuudella ymmärretään nykyaikaisissa yhteiskunnissa kaikille kansalaisille asetettua velvollisuutta hankkia itselleen tietty perussivistys. Suomi otti käyttöön oppivelvollisuuden vuoden 1921 oppivelvollisuuslailla, joka määräsi kaikille pakolliseksi vähintään kuusivuotisen kansakoulun oppimäärän suorittamisen. Käyttöönotto tapahtui verrattain myöhään, sillä oppivelvollisuudesta ei ollut onnistuttu säätämään Venäjän alaisuudessa. Oppivelvollisuutta myös vastustettiin, sillä kansakoulun pelättiin olevan yhteiskunnalle kallis ja kasvattavan huonoja työntekijöitä. Käytännössä oppivelvollisuus toteutui suurimmassa osassa maata jo 1920-luvulla, mutta Tunturi-Lapissa viimeiset syrjäkylät saatiin kouluverkon piiriin vasta 1950-luvulla. Suomessa oppivelvollisuus alkaa yleensä sinä vuonna, kun lapsi täyttää seitsemän vuotta. Koulun aloittamista voidaan kuitenkin siirtää vuodella myöhemmäksi tai aikaisemmaksi. Yleisimmin oppivelvollisuus suoritetaan peruskoulussa, joka opettaa oppimäärään kuuluvia oppiaineita. split_passages_en: The Compulsory Education Act was Finland's law on compulsory education, which was confirmed on April 15, 1921. Finland's law on compulsory education came quite late in the European legislative environment, and only Belgium got a law dealing with the issue after Finland. In Finland, the Compulsory Education Act, in contrast to almost all other Western countries, does not impose compulsory schooling, but regulates the subjects to be taught, which are defined by other laws and regulations. Today, basic education and compulsory education are regulated in the Basic Education Act in Finland. Finland's industrial rise from the 1860s also greatly affected the country's cultural aspirations and the living conditions of the people. This is how the language regulations, the liberalization of the land trade, the national school and, of course, the regular functioning of the country parliaments (state parliaments) came into force. What was new in Finnish society was mobility, because the salary regulations had been removed and people were free to move so

Compulsory education is understood as the obligation imposed on all citizens in modern societies to acquire a certain basic education. Finland introduced compulsory education with the Compulsory Education Act of 1921, which made it mandatory for everyone to complete at least a six-year public school curriculum. The implementation took place relatively late, as compulsory education had not been successfully regulated under Russia. Compulsory education was also opposed, as it was feared that public schools would be expensive for society and produce bad workers. In practice, compulsory schooling was already implemented in most of the country in the 1920s, but in Tunturi-Lap, the last remote villages were covered by the school network only in the 1950s. In Finland, compulsory schooling usually starts the year a child turns seven. However, starting school can be postponed a year later or earlier. Compulsory education is most commonly carried out in elementary school, which teaches subjects included in the curriculum. Compulsory education

In 1817, a night curfew was imposed on Lapua that applied to Sunday evenings, which in 1843 was extended to weekdays as well. The wording of the 7th section of the Lapua government regulation reads as follows: "Those, i.e. those of the working people, who, without a legal and necessary matter, stay away after ten o'clock on the evening from the 1st of May to the 1st of September, and after nine o'clock on the evening at any other time. from home, let them be fined two hundred rubles each time they do so." In Laihia, the night curfew came into use in 1818, but in Isossakyrö only in 1842. In the middle of the century (1840–59), the night curfew was in force in all three (Isokyrö, Vähäkyrö, Laihia) parishes in Kyrönmaa, Mustasaari, Maalahti, Vöyri and Lapua, and in their chapel congregations. The night curfew established for Seinäjoki in 1871

The history of the Soviet Union covers the years 1922−1991. The Soviet Union was born on December 30, 1922, when Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Transcaucasia united. The predecessor of the Soviet Union was Soviet Russia. Social unrest, boredom with the autocratic rule of the emperor, battle fatigue caused by the First World War and long-simmering revolutionism finally led to the collapse of the Russian Empire in 1917. Power was first taken by a provisional government led mainly by the Duma, which, however, fell within a year when the Bolshevik party took the dominant position under the leadership of its leader, Vladimir Lenin. The series of events known as the October Revolution, which began with a coup d'état on November 7, 1917, led to a civil war in which the main antagonists were the socialist "Reds" and the (counter-revolutionary), "Whites" supported by foreign powers. Shortly after the Bolsheviks came to power, Finland recognized independence from the Russian Empire. As Russia broke up into separate whites led by military governments

According to Nestor's Chronicle, the history of Russia as its own kingdom began when some Slavic and Finno-Ugric tribes called the Varangian Rurik their prince. Rurik settled in Novgorod and the people of Novgorod named their land "Russkaja zemlja" 'Land of Russia'. However, the reality of this fable is very unclear. Russia is Finland's neighbor to the east, which is why Finland and Russia have a long common history. Finland was an autonomous part of the Russian Empire between 1809 and 1917. The Empire fell in the revolutions of 1917 and after a long civil war, the Soviet Union was formed in 1922 under the leadership of Russia. split_passages_en: Vincenzo Bellini (November 3, 1801, Catania, Sicily – September 23, 1835, Puteaux, Paris) was an Italian opera composer, master of lyric opera, and standard-bearer of bel Canto. Bellini's first success was "Il Pirata", which La Scala had commissioned from him in 1827. Today, his masterpiece is generally considered to be "Norma", which the composer created in 1831. After composing "Puritans", Bellini fell ill and died at the age of 33 near Paris. He was later buried in his hometown of Catania. split_passages_en: Afrikaner nationalism () is a late 19th-century movement that considered Afrikaners to be the "chosen people" and aimed to unify the white Afrikaans-speaking population of South Africa as a reaction to British imperialism. Afrikaner nationalism emphasized the cultural unity of all Afrikaners and opposed "foreign" elements such as blacks, Jews, and English-speaking South Africans. Its central concepts included the "Volk", an independent nation of all white Afrikaans-speaking South Africans. Afrikaner nationalism was a key factor in the birth of the apartheid system. The central institutions of Afrikaner nationalism were the National Party, which ruled the country from 1948 until 1994, and the secret society "Broederbond". Historian T. Dunbar Moodie has proposed that Afrikaner nationalism as represented by the "Broederbond" was a kind of civic religion that combined key symbolic elements such as Afrikaner history, Afrikaans

unity and opposed "foreign" elements such as blacks, Jews and English-speaking South Africans. Its central concepts included the "Volk", an independent nation of all white Afrikaans-speaking South Africans. The history of the Afrikaners was depicted as a drama of suffering, in which events caused by the British such as the Great Migration and the Boer Wars were repeated. Afrikaner nationalism played a key role in the birth of the apartheid system, and its most important institutions were the National Party and the Broederbond secret society. The first Boers settled on Hyväntoivonniemi in the area of ​​present-day Kapmaa in 1652. By 1707, 1,779 immigrants had settled in Kapmaa: Dutch and German and French Protestants, or Huguenots. Families who moved inland from the coast were called "trekboers", or wandering farmers. The designation was soon shortened to "Boer". language and Calvinism. The history of the Afrikaners was depicted as a recurring drama of suffering caused by events such as the Great Migration and the Boer Wars caused by the British. In the 1920s and 1930s, a small group of members of the "Broederbond" organization consciously set out to form a "Christian-nationalist" identity for all white Afrikaans-speaking South Africans. One motive for the promotion of national identity was to create "volkskapitalisme" or people's capitalism in the country, which sought to eliminate the clear economic inequality between English- and Afrikaans-speaking whites. The adoption of the new Afrikaner identity was slow, however, and was not widely adopted until around 1961, when South Africa became a republic and seceded from the Commonwealth. In the 1990s, the National Party had to admit that its apartheid policy had failed. After apartheid, Afrikaner nationalism has lost most of its previous support. The first representatives of Afrikaner nationalism were Stephanus Jacobus

split_passages_en: burlesque originated in the 19th century on the basis of variety and vaudeville theater. In London, England, burlesque had already been popular since the 1830s. London burlesque was a bold musical theater parody that parodied a well-known opera, play or ballet performance. The pioneer of burlesque in the United States was the British actress Lydia Thompson. His British Blondes troupe reformed burlesque from a theatrical parody to a sexier one starting in the 1860s and popularized it in the United States. At that time, burlesque stars and shows were very popular, and every major American city had several burlesque venues. The dance performances were interspersed with performances by comedians, and the satirical roots of the genre were still visible in the theatrical performances. After Thompson, burlesque moved from the entertainment of the middle and upper classes to the theaters of the working class. At the same time, its content began to be emphasized more and more by the feminine forms that appeared

Burlesque (, 'joking, exaggeratedly crazy, grotesque, parodying, grinning') originally means parodic humor entertainment performed by means of the theater, which usually includes sketches. It is often considered a direct continuation of Commedia dell'arte, although the term was born around the same time as Commedia dell'arte. In literature and as a cultural stylistic direction, burlesque means showing the serious to be laughable through the contradiction of its subject and style on the one hand. Today, burlesque often refers to cabaret-like stage entertainment, which includes humor and striptease, born from the North American music hall entertainment of the 19th century. In the 18th century, the burlesque stylistic direction was a literary form in which a high subject was depicted in a low style and vice versa. In its American sense, burlesque refers to stage entertainment, which traditionally includes dancing, teasing striptease and femininely decorative performance costumes. American

Burberry () is a traditional English fashion house founded in 1856. Burberry is known for its check pattern. The current chief designer is the Englishman Christopher Bailey, who has taken the house to a new height, among other things, by rejecting the excessive use of the traditional check pattern. The founder of Burberry was Thomas Burberry (1835–1926), who in 1880 patented a water-repellent, durable and breathable gabardine fabric. The company's name was originally Burberry. It was later changed to "Burberry's" because customers called it Burberry's of London. The name was returned back to Burberry only in 1998 for marketing purposes. Gabardine overcoats manufactured by Burberry or similar were previously called "berberi" in Finland. Burberry has been criticized for supporting animal cruelty because it uses real fur in its products. The company justifies its use of fur in particular

usually recorded music, while traditional burlesque was always accompanied by live music. Burlesque is characterized by gentle glorification of femininity and humor, in modern times also by challenging today's beauty standards and idealizing various female bodies. Although burlesque includes sneaky movements and undressing, the burlesque performer does not take off all her clothes, because the purpose of the performance is not to excite but to tease and entertain. In the past, the closest burlesque theater in Finland was Kabaree Punainen Mylly, which operated between 1946 and 1965 under the direction of Ossi Elstelä. Neoburlesque came to Finland at the end of the first decade of the 2000s. Finland's first burlesque festival was the Helsinki Burlesque Festival in 2008 at Restaurant Kaisaniemi.

split_passages_en: The Battle of Madagascar, or Operation Ironclad (Finnish: "Armored Ship"), was an Allied attack on Vichy French-administered Madagascar in World War II. The fighting started on May 5, 1942, and didn't end until November 6. The battle ended in victory for the Allies. Japanese Navy submarines patrolled the Indian Ocean freely after the conquest of Southeast Asia. Madagascar would have provided a port for the Japanese fleet if it had sought to continue its conquests to the west. The Japanese submarines stationed in Madagascar would have significantly complicated or even cut off the Hyväntoivonnemi sea route and thus jeopardized the maintenance of the British 8th Army in North Africa. In addition, in March 1942, the Japanese naval division invaded the Indian Ocean, which caused the British Eastern Fleet to move from the northeastern parts of the Indian Ocean and the fleet's home port had to be moved all the way to Kilindi in British East Africa

conquered most of the island and proclaimed himself king of Madagascar in 1818. He concluded a trade agreement with Britain and invited English missionaries to his capital. In the early 19th century, missionaries created the Malagasy literary language based on the Latin alphabet. Ranavalona I, who ruled between 1828 and 1861, expelled the English and waged war against the French. The practice of Christianity was banned in 1835. Britain and France declared a trade embargo on Madagascar and bombarded the port of Toamasina in 1845. Radama II, who ruled between 1861 and 1863, abolished the standing army and gave Europeans considerable privileges. He was killed in the rebellion that broke out in 1863. The government led by Prime Minister Rainilaiarivony improved the country's administration and created a new privileged service status for the peasants. Slavery was limited and foreign trade was developed. Sugar factories and vanilla factories were established in the country

in rough seas. The fighting continued for several months. During the summer, the troops of the British 5th Division were transferred to India and on June 22 the East African Brigade (King's African Rifles) arrived in Madagascar. A reinforced South African 7th Motorized Brigade and the Rhodesian 27th Infantry Brigade landed a few weeks later. The 29th Brigade and a reinforced 22nd Brigade carried out a landing at Majunga on 10 September to complete combat operations before the onset of the rainy season. The Vichy troops had made numerous break-ins on the main roads and succeeded in slowing down the advance of the landed troops inland. However, the allied forces managed to capture the capital of the island, Tananarive, and then the town of Ambalavao. After this, there was only the capture of Andriamanalina on October 18. Vichy forces surrendered on November 8 near Ilhosy in the south of the island.

passage_in_language: <0> Ranskan vallankumoussodat olivat sarja vuosina 1792–1802 käytyjä sotia, joissa pääosapuolina olivat yhtäältä Ranskan ensimmäinen tasavalta ja toisaalta ensimmäisen ja toisen liittokunnan jäsenet. Ensimmäisen liittokunnan sota käytiin vuosina 1792–1797 ja toisen liittokunnan sota 1799–1801. Ranskan suuri vallankumous alkoi 1789. Vallankumoukselliset pelkäsivät ulkovaltojen suunnittelevan Ranskan-vastaista sotaa vanhan järjestelmän ("l’ancien régime") palauttamiseksi. Ranskan vallankumousta pidetään yhtenä Euroopan historian merkittävimmistä tapahtumista, ja historiantutkimuksessa siitä katsotaan yleensä alkavaksi uusin aika, jolla porvarit ovat valtaapitäviä. Ranskan vallankumous seurasi Amerikan vallankumousta. split_passages_en: The French Revolutionary Wars were a series of wars fought between 1792 and 1802, in which the main parties were the French First Republic on the one hand, and members of the First and Second Confederations on the other. The War of the First Confederation was fought in 1792–1797 and the War of the Second Confederation in 1799–1801. The Great French Revolution began in 1789. The revolutionaries feared that foreign powers were planning a war against France to restore the old system ("l'ancien régime"). This fear was influenced by the so-called Pillnitz Declaration (1791). The Girondists in particular demanded war in the French Legislative National Assembly. France declared war on Austria in 1792. Prussia joined the war on the Austrian side and Austro-Prussian forces attacked France. The French won the Battle of Valmy, after which they invaded the Austrian Netherlands, won the Battle of Jemappes and occupied the Austrian Netherlands. In November 1792 France

The Great French Revolution was a social revolution that started in France in 1789 and the period that followed it, lasting until 1799, when the absolutist monarchy, feudal society and feudal privileges of the previous ancien régime were abolished. The French Revolution is considered one of the most significant events in European history, and in historical research it is generally considered to be the beginning of the latest period in which the bourgeoisie is in power. The French Revolution followed the American Revolution. Many of the most central values ​​of modern democracy are derived from the French Revolution, such as people's power, human rights and the rule of law. At the same time, the position of the Catholic Church changed completely, as it lost its status as the state religion, and freedom of thought and belief was accepted in France. The ideological content of the revolution is often summed up in the slogan "Freedom, brotherhood and equality". The reforms of the revolution were not limited to France

took a more radical turn, the monarchy was abolished and the first republic was established. King Louis XVI was sentenced to death. The rise to power of the Jacobins, who represented the radical extreme line, led to a dictatorial phase called the Time of Terror in 1793–1794, when opponents of the revolution were severely persecuted and thousands of people were executed by guillotine. After the overthrow of Maximilien Robespierre, who ruled almost as a dictator, there followed a phase called the Directory period from 1795 to 1799, when attempts to rise to power by both pro-royalists and extreme leftists were suppressed. The revolution is considered to have ended in 1799, when General Napoleon Bonaparte came to power in a military coup. He abolished the republic when he crowned himself emperor in 1804. After the fall of Napoleon in 1814 and 1815, the period of restoration began, when the order that preceded the revolution was tried to be restored. However, many of the effects of the revolution proved irreversible. They led to the revolution

The lute, which was developed in the Middle Ages, has its origins in a similar instrument invented in the Middle East. A baroque lute can be recognized by its wide fingerboard, during the Renaissance the fingerboard was narrower. The lute came to Europe from the Middle East either through the population movement caused by the Crusaders or through trade. In the Middle Ages, lutes were small, 4- or 5-string instruments that were plucked at the base of the sula. During the Renaissance, strings were added and the lute was played with the fingers. At the same time, Lutes of different sizes with different sound ranges were also developed. Lute music was very popular in the era, and many works were composed for the instrument. Clay bricks are a building material made from sand, clay, water and some fibrous material such as sticks, straw or manure. The material is shaped into a brick with the help of a mold, which is allowed to dry in the sun. Such bricks were used in Egypt as early as 3000 BC. Later, the hardening of bricks by burning was invented. Clay brick buildings are very durable: the oldest preserved buildings are made of clay bricks. There must be clay near the place where the bricks are made. Brick factories were established next to clay extraction sites. The brick can be a red fired clay brick or a gray sun-dried clay brick. Brick factories have been located in many villages and towns since the Second World War when construction accelerated. Today, brick is mainly used in renovation construction or in new developments, if desired, specifically brick instead of other alternatives.

split_passages_en: The flag of the Netherlands, or prince's flag, is the emblem of the Netherlands, along with the coat of arms, motto and national anthem. It was introduced in 1579 after the Protestant provinces defeated the rebellion led by William I of Orange, Count of Nassau, against Spanish rule. The colors of the Dutch tricolor were initially orange, white and blue in accordance with the colors of William's ruling family. The orange later changed to red. The size ratio of the ticket is 2:3. The flag of the Netherlands and the flag of Luxembourg are similar except that the flag of Luxembourg is longer and its blue stripe is lighter.

The national flag is a flag that serves as the national symbol of a state or country. Originally, flags were used as symbols of ruling families. The nation adopted the use of flags with the French Revolution in the 18th century. In this way, national flags were born and the design of flags was simplified. Three-quarters of the current national flags are from the post-World War II period, and only 12 countries have a flag that was adopted before 1800. The oldest national flag is that of Denmark, which dates from the 13th century. National flags are almost always rectangular, unlike the flags of medieval armies that preceded them, which were more variable in shape. National flags can still change or change at the turns of history. The different colors of the national flag often have a certain meaning. The flags of some countries have the coat of arms of the ruling family. Sometimes a ticket

The Finnish flag, or the blue cross flag, is one of Finland's national symbols. The flag has a sea blue cross on a white background. The pattern is based on the Nordic cross flag. Parliament approved the blue cross flag as Finland's national flag on May 28, 1918, and the Senate confirmed the law the next day. Before that, there had been a discussion about, among other things, the colors of the flag, some supported a blue-white and some a red-yellow flag. At the beginning of the year, the Senate had proposed the so-called lion flag as the national flag. The blue cross flag was ultimately designed by Eero Snellman and Bruno Tuukkanen. There are three different types of flags for their purpose: the national flag, i.e. the standard blue cross flag, the rectangular national flag and the tabbed national flag. In Finland, there are six official flag days and ten established flag days per year. However, everyone has the right to fly the Finnish flag when they see fit

Inspired by former Microsoft employee Michael Abrash, Newell left Microsoft and founded Valve Software together with his former colleague Mike Harrington in 1996. The Colombian civil war is a guerrilla and drug war that has lasted sixty years. The parties to the war have been generally left-wing guerilla movements opposed to the government such as FARC, ELN and M-19, the army, paramilitary groups that gave birth to the far-right AUC, and the United States. Usually, the war is considered to have started in 1964 or 1965, when the communist guerrillas became active. Some consider the violent rural civil war known as "La Violencia" between conservatives and liberals that began as early as 1948 as the start of the war. Drug cartels became involved in guerrilla warfare in the 1980s and could side with the government or the guerrillas. The Colombian government and guerilla movements have tried from time to time to rub the peace. The peace attempt of the early 1980s failed miserably. Uusikaupunki (, originally "Kalainen") is a coastal city in Finland. It belongs to the province of Varsinais-Suomi and the region of Vakka-Suomi. Uusikaupunki is the main center of its district. The city is known for, among other things, the car factory and the wooden house center based on the grid pattern. King Gustav II Adolf founded the city in 1617, so Uusikaupunki is the 12th oldest city in Finland. Uusilakaupunki also has a part in European history, as the peace of the Great Northern War was declared there in 1721. The city flourished especially in the 19th century, when the shipbuilding period was lived. In addition to the center of Uusikaupunki, the city includes the former municipalities of Uusikaupunki rural district, Kalanti, Lokalahti and Pyhämaa. The neighboring municipalities are Kustavi, Laitila, Pyhäranta, Taivassalo and Vehmaa. Uusikaupunki is located in Varsinais-Suomi province, Vakka-Suomi region. The city is located on the shore of the Gulf of Pohjan, 70 kilometers northwest of Turku.

The track cycling world championships are the most important track cycling competitions together with track cycling at the Olympics. The competitions were organized for the first time in 1893 and have been held every year since then, except for the war years 1915–1919 and 1940–1945. The organizing country's cycling association organizes the competitions under the supervision of the International Cycling Federation. The first World Championships organized in Chicago were intended only for amateurs. At the 1895 Games in Copenhagen, there were also sports for professionals for the first time. Separate World Championship titles for professionals and amateurs were awarded until the 1992 Games, after which competition has been held in categories open to all. There are currently (2010) a total of 19 sports in the program of the World Championships. The sports for both men and women are time trial, keirin, individual pursuit, team pursuit, points race, line race, heat race, team sprint and omnium. The men's program also includes a pair race.

split_passages_en: John Malcolm Thorpe Fleming "Jack" Churchill, DSO & Bar, MC & Bar (16 September 1906 Hong Kong, British – 8 March 1996 Surrey, England, United Kingdom), nicknamed Fighting Jack Churchill and Mad Jack, was a British soldier, with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel . He served in the commando forces of the British Army during the Second World War. The famous and eccentric Churchill used a longbow and the Scottish "Claybeg" broadsword as his service weapons. Churchill was born in British Hong Kong in 1906 to an old Oxfordshire family. His father, Alec, worked in public works agencies in Ceylon and Hong Kong. Churchill studied at King William's College in the Isle of Man. He enjoyed playing the bagpipes and archery. Thanks to these skills, he got a small role in Douglas Fairbanks' film "The Thief of Bagdad". Churchill graduated

where he also got excited about surfing. After returning to England, he became the first man to surf the Severn River on a two meter tidal wave. He also designed his own surfboard. Churchill finally retired from the army in 1959. Among other things, he spent his retirement days sailing with his wife on the River Thames and building remote-controlled miniature models of ships, especially warships. He died at his home in Surrey in 1996. Churchill's younger brother Tom Churchill rose to the rank of Major General before retiring in 1962. Churchill's youngest brother, nicknamed Buster, joined the navy and was present during the Invergordon Rebellion in 1931. Buster died while taking part in protecting convoys in Malta in 1942. Churchill married the daughter of a Scottish ship owner with Rosamund Denny in the spring of 1941 and they had two during their 55-year marriage

Sir Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill () was a politician and Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1940 to 1945 and from 1951 to 1955. Churchill is best known for his role as Prime Minister in World War II, but he was also a politician who served as a Member of Parliament for 62 years, a World War I Secretary of the Navy, a professional soldier in the Boer War, and a 1953 Nobel Prize-winning author. Churchill was born at Blenheim Palace near the town of Woodstock in Oxfordshire. General John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough, Prince of Mindelheim, KG, PC (26 May 1650 – 16 June 1722) was an English military commander and statesman who served under a total of five different monarchs. He began as a lowly paas in the court of the Stuart family and served James, Duke of York in the 1670s and early 1680s, earning military and political promotions for his bravery and diplomatic skills. Churchill's role in putting down the Monmouth Rebellion in 1685 helped secure James's accession to the throne, but just three years later he abandoned his Catholic favorite for the Protestant Dutch William of Orange. At William's coronation, he was granted the earldom of Marlborough as a tribute for his subservience. passage_in_language: <0> Maanjäristys on Maan peruskallion tärähtelyä, joka on voimakkaana hyvin tuhoisaa rakennuksille ja ihmisille. Heikko järistys heiluttaa lamppuja, voimakas järistys romahduttaa talot, hyvin voimakas myllää maaperääkin. Meren pohjassa tapahtunut maanjäristys voi aiheuttaa voimakkaan hyökyaallon, tsunamin. Maanjäristyksen maanalainen tapahtumapaikka on hyposentrumi, ja maanpintakeskus episentrumi. Maanjäristysaallot eli seismiset aallot jaetaan pitkittäisiin ja poikittaisiin aaltoihin sekä pinta-aaltoihin. Järistysaaltojen heijastumisia ja taittumisia tutkimalla voidaan selvittää jossain määrin peruskallion ja koko Maan rakennetta. Maanjäristyksiä pystytään toteamaan kaukaakin seismometriksi tai seismografiksi kutsutulla laitteella. Maanjäristyksen rekisteröintiä kutsutaan seismogrammiksi. Globaalit maanjäristykset luokitellaan hyposentrumin syvyyden perusteella mataliin ("h" < 70 km), keskisyviin ("h" = 70–300 km) ja syviin ("h" = <1> 300–700 km). Seismogrammit jaetaan neljään luokkaan sen perusteella, mikä on seismometrin ja järistyksen episentrumin välinen kulmaetäisyys kilometreinä tai asteina (1° = 111,2 km): Maanjäristyksen voimaa mitataan yleensä Richterin asteikolla ja tuhoisuutta Mercallin asteikolla. Järistykset, jotka ovat voimakkuudeltaan yli seitsemän Richterin asteikolla, ovat suuria, ja niitä tapahtuu maapallolla vuodessa noin 15. Kun tutkitaan alueita, joiden luontainen seismisyys on hyvin alhainen, voidaan käyttää edellisestä poikkeavaa luokittelua. Maanjäristyksiä syntyy muun muassa mannerlaattojen liikkuessa toistensa suhteen sekä tulivuorenpurkausten, asteroiditörmäysten, maanvyöryjen ja luolaromahdusten takia. Ihmistoimintakin voi laukaista maanjäristyksiä. Maanjäristyksiä esiintyy eniten mannerlaattojen raja-alueilla, joissa on runsasta tulivuoritoimintaakin. Räjäytykset, kaivostoiminta, onnettomuudet ja muu ihmistoiminta synnyttävät omaleimaisia <2> maanjäristysaaltoja. Kun on tarve erottaa ne oikeista maanjäristyksistä, niitä voidaan kutsua yleisemmin seismisiksi tapauksiksi. Tektoniset maanjäristykset tapahtuvat siirroksissa eli paikoissa, joissa kalliolohkot liukuvat toisiaan vasten. Kalliolohkojen välistä liikettä vastustaa niiden välinen kitka. Jos kitka lukitsee siirroksen, syntyy jännityskertymä. Jännitys jatkaa kasvamistaan, ja lopulta siirros murtuu ja siihen varastoitunut energia vapautuu maanjäristyksenä. Järistyksen voimakkuus riippuu siirrostason pinta-alasta sekä keskimääräisestä siirtymästä. Jännityksen purkautuminen alkaa järistyksen hyposentrumista eli "fokuksesta" eli "pesäkkeestä". Siirrokset jaetaan geologisesti kolmeen päätyyppiin: normaalisiirroksiin, käänteissiirroksiin ja kulku-liukusiirroksiin. Normaalisiirroksia esiintyy tavallisesti alueilla, joissa maankuori venyy eli on ekstensiossa. Käänteissiirroksia on alueilla, joissa kuorta puristetaan sivusuunnassa kasaan. Kulku-liukusiirroksessa lohkot liikkuvat sivusuunnassa toisiaan
split_passages_en: An earthquake is a vibration of the Earth's bedrock, which, when strong, is very destructive to buildings and people. A weak earthquake shakes lamps, a strong earthquake collapses houses, a very strong one shakes the soil. An earthquake at the bottom of the sea can cause a strong tidal wave, a tsunami. The underground location of an earthquake is the hypocenter, and the surface center is the epicenter. Earthquake waves, or seismic waves, are divided into longitudinal and transverse waves and surface waves. By studying the reflections and refractions of earthquake waves, the structure of the bedrock and the entire Earth can be determined to some extent. Earthquakes can be detected from afar with a device called a seismometer or seismograph. The recording of an earthquake is called a seismogram. Based on the depth of the hypocenter, global earthquakes are classified as shallow ("h" < 70 km), medium ("h" = 70–300 km) and deep ("h" =

300–700 km). split_passages_en: Cannibalism means eating an individual of the same species. An animal that eats members of its own species is also called a cannibal. A person who eats another person is called a man-eater or anthropophagus. The term "cannibal" comes from Spanish. When Christopher Columbus arrived in America, he assumed that the people of Haiti would be subjects of the Great Khan of China. When preparing for the meeting, he had with him experts in Arabic and Hebrew. When he heard the name Caniba or Canima, he assumed the word referred to the dog-headed people (cane-bal) described by Mendeville. Samuel Purchas has argued that the word means "brazen men" in the Carib language. Richard Hakluyt brought the word to England and Shakespeare used it in his play "The Tempest" as the name of the monster Caliban. Cannibalism is generally considered a food taboo. However, it has been practiced in those related to religion and warfare

expulsion of life force. In funeral rituals, it is done to ensure the immortality of a respected member of the tribe. Taking over the life force of a slain enemy is probably more common. For example, in the 17th century, the Jesuits say that the Iroquois and Hurons practiced ritual cannibalism precisely because of this principle. Unless an enemy was adopted, they were more likely to be tortured, and if the enemy proved brave, their heart or flesh could be eaten, thus transferring the enemy's power to the eaters. Among the Atna Indians, cannibalism was based on the belief that the spirit of the fallen could be avenged unless the warrior ate a little fat near the heart of the slain enemy. In folklore, cannibalism is associated with evil, e.g. in the fairy tale "Hannu and Kerttu". In mythology, cannibalism has been extended to a universal principle, as in the case of the Hindu god Kali. Kali is said to have drunk the demons

for example traces of meat cutting. Researchers have speculated that cannibalism was not only a ritual, but also a way to fulfill the need for food and a way to benefit from territorial disputes. Cannibalism has been found in the Americas, especially during the Aztec flower wars. Large numbers of enemies captured in the Aztec wars were first sacrificed to the gods, then the corpses were prepared for food according to customary customs. A stew was made from the dismembered body parts, which was seasoned with tomatoes and pepper. Cannibalism has been known to be practiced during the First Crusade. Some Crusaders are known to have eaten the bodies of their dead enemies after the conquest of Ma'arat. It was also practiced on the march to Jerusalem. It was probably a combination of hunger and fever, possibly also the desire to terrorize the enemy. Some refused to eat the flesh of their fellow Christians, but ate the bodies of slain Muslims. split_passages_en: Occitan ("occitan" or "lenga d'òc") is a Romance language divided into six main dialects, spoken mainly in France, Italy and Spain. The name of the language comes from the word "òc" meaning "yes". Of the main Romance languages, the closest to Occitan is Catalan. Occitan is a rich language, especially in vocabulary related to countryside and nature. It is debatable whether there is a single Occitan language at all or whether certain dialects such as Gascon should be considered their own languages. On the other hand, for example, in the cultural dictionary of "Nykysuomi sanakirja" from 1977, Occitan was still defined as the southern dialect of Provençal. Occitan is sometimes mistakenly called Provençal, which is however only one of the Occitan dialects. Over the centuries, Occitan has had many names: lenga romana, roman, limousin, raimondin, gascon, catalan, provençal,

poets often wrote in Occitan. In the early 15th century, the poet Ausiàs March, who lived in Beniarjó and was also known as Gandian, worked in favor of the expressive use of Catalan (or Valencian) in poetry. Occitan and Catalan today differ, among other things, in their orthographies. Occitan is written in a way that is closer to medieval spelling, while Catalans have chosen an orthography that more closely matches their pronunciation (for example, the absence of the final "n" in "català" 'Catalan'). The majority of Occitan speakers live in France, while a clear majority of Catalan speakers live in Spain. The vocabularies of the languages ​​have also diverged over the years and regional variations within both languages ​​have differentiated the languages ​​from each other. Johanson-Blizzard syndrome or JBS is a very rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder that occurs in children born alive in Europe with a probability of approximately 1 in 250,000 (0.0004%). More than 100 cases have been reported worldwide. The syndrome is named after Ann J. Johanson and Robert M. Blizzard, who first described it in 1971. The gene associated with the disease was identified by Martin Zenker et al. in 2005. The manifestation of the disease and its degree of severity vary greatly between those affected by it, and not all the symptoms associated with the disease are present in any single person. On the other hand, there are very mild forms of the disease, in which mild and infrequent symptoms gradually accumulate and the severity of the disease increases as the child grows.
